comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: See this from Irish Indo How the other half lived Women participating in an otter hunt, in Curraghmore, Portlaw, Co Waterford, in May, 1901.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Curraghmore, meaning great bog, is the last of 4 castles built by the de la Poer family after their arrival in Ireland in 1167. The Castle walls are about 12 feet thick and within one, a tight spiral stairway connects the lower ground floor with the roof above. 

Of the many curious and interesting features of Curraghmore, the most striking is the courtyard front of the house, where the original Castle is encased in a spectacular Victorian mansion with flanking Georgian ranges.

The combination of architectural features from several periods around the ancient core of the original castle produces a most striking composition; "immediately recognizable and undeniably moving", as it was described by Country Life.

comment.author: 79549245@N06

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Like your location - near the river, the obvious place to find otters - hunted because they killed Salmon and Trout.

Of course Otters are a protected species now. Saw one last year up close and personal - a magnificent animal.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I can't give a 25" map link for where the dogs are in this photo, but here is one for where they lived. The river flowing through the estate (most likely the one they are hunting on) is the river Clodagh. The 5th Marquess of Waterford, John Henry De La Poer Beresford, named his daughter Clodagh in 1879 after the river, and the name is still common enough (not a Top 100 name, but not rare). (Edit: Happy New Year to all!)

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's a distant shot of the kennel house for good measure! (Happy New Year All!)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The London Times of 20th May 1901 says The Countess Cadogan, on her arrival on Saturday from Curraghmore ... . Saturday was the 18th, so presumably she was at Curraghmore on the 14th. I wonder if she is one of the ladies in the picture [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] referenced. And I bet the chap in my avatar wasn't a million miles away. And a happy new year to all.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Lady Clodagh Beresford was married at the end of Feb 1901, a couple of <s>weeks</s> months before this photo was taken.
